elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two new 2D coordination polymers, [Ag4(μ-4,4'-bpp)3(1,3-bdc)2] n  ⋅2nH2O (1) and [Ag(μ-4,4'-bpp)2ClO4] n  (2) (4,4'-bpp=2,2'-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1'-biphenylene; 1,3-bdc=1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) have been synthesized. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complexes 1 and 2 exhibit different types of four-connected square planes with (4,4) topology. In 1, weak ligand-unsupported Ag⋯Ag interactions and conjugated π systems with additional aromatic rings favor the development of the structure. In 2, the corrugated (4,4) sheets are packed in the ab planes and stacked along the c direction with the anions     ClO   4     -     occupying the gaps in the squares.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two new 2D coordination polymers, [Ag4(μ-4,4'-bpp)3(1,3-bdc)2] n  ⋅2nH2O (1) and [Ag(μ-4,4'-bpp)2ClO4] n (2) (4,4'-bpp=2,2'-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1'-biphenylene; 1,3-bdc=1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) have been synthesized using three-layer diffusion methods. Single-crystal X-ray analyses reveal that they are both extended grid networks of the (4,4) topology. In complex 1, a chain built by Ag(I) centers with T-shaped and linear geometries is further connected by the interesting ligand-unsupported Ag⋯Ag interactions as well as the conjugated π systems to form an interdigitated 2-D coordination network. The corrugated (4,4) sheets of 2 are packed in the ab planes and stacked along the c direction with the anions     ClO   4     -     occupying the gaps in the squares.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Much interest in molecular crystal engineering is fueled not only by esthetic aspects but also the beauty of crystal morphologies, then certainly by the symmetry and complexity of the crystal structures . Crystal engineering paves the road for many potential practical applications in functional materials and for understanding of molecular self-assembly procedures . The fact that the integrity of the building blocks is preserved during the synthesis and ultimately translated into the resulting assembled network offers numerous opportunities for designing frameworks with desirable topologies and architectures . So far, a great number of bis(pyridine)-functionalized ligands with different angles between their binding sites have been rationally designed, synthesized, and treated with transition metal complexes with diverse features . Among this kind of system, optically active 1,1-bi-2-naphthol (BINOL) has been widely used as a starting material and auxiliary in asymmetric synthesis and chiral recognition owing to its axial chirality and configurational stability . During our previous work, a series of optically active <ce:italic>exo</ce:italic>-bidentate ligands, such as (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-2,2-bis(3-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1-bi-naphthalene [(<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>] and (<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-2,2-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1-bi-naphthalene [(<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>)-L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] have been synthesized by introducing pyridine-donor ligands group into 2,2-positions of BINOL and assembly with Ag(I) salts resulted in several interesting complexes with unique helicate or helix-like structure motifs . However, it is still difficult, if not impossible, to predict the structural topology accurately on the basis of ligands. Therefore, it is a desirable goal to comprehend the factors that contribute to the final structures of coordination polymers. Recently, 2,2′-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1′-biphenylene (4,4′-bpp), as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>, a flexible N-donor ligand bearing dipyridyl connectors, has been synthesized in our group.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Much interest in molecular crystal engineering is fueled not only by esthetic aspects but also the beauty of crystal morphologies, then certainly by the symmetry and complexity of the crystal structures . Crystal engineering paves the road for many potential practical applications in functional materials and for understanding of molecular self-assembly procedures . The fact that the integrity of the building blocks is preserved during the synthesis and ultimately translated into the resulting assembled network offers numerous opportunities for designing frameworks with desirable topologies and architectures . So far, a great number of bis(pyridine)-functionalized ligands with different angles between their binding sites have been rationally designed, synthesized, and treated with transition metal complexes with diverse features . Among this kind of system, optically active 1,1-bi-2-naphthol (BINOL) has been widely used as a starting material and auxiliary in asymmetric synthesis and chiral recognition owing to its axial chirality and configurational stability . During our previous work, a series of optically active exo-bidentate ligands, such as (S)-2,2-bis(3-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1-bi-naphthalene [(S)-L1] and (S)-2,2-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1-bi-naphthalene [(S)-L2] have been synthesized by introducing pyridine-donor ligands group into 2,2-positions of BINOL and assembly with Ag(I) salts resulted in several interesting complexes with unique helicate or helix-like structure motifs . However, it is still difficult, if not impossible, to predict the structural topology accurately on the basis of ligands. Therefore, it is a desirable goal to comprehend the factors that contribute to the final structures of coordination polymers. Recently, 2,2'-bis(4-pyridylmethyleneoxy)-1,1'-biphenylene (4,4'-bpp), as shown in  , a flexible N-donor ligand bearing dipyridyl connectors, has been synthesized in our group.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">And from a structural point of view, 4,4′-bpp ligand appears to has some advantages: (1) the research on biphenyl bridge containing 4,4′-bpp ligands provides a simple probe for investigation of chiral complexes derived from 1,1-bi-2-naphthol; (2) the flexible nature and the long distance between two pyridyl rings of 4,4′-bpp give rise to the possibility of creating interesting structures with cavities, pores or consequently channels . In addition, Ag(I) ion is a good transition metal precursor for coordination polymers, because it can adopt certain coordination geometries, such as linear, trigonal and tetrahedral coordination modes, and has high affinity for hard donors like nitrogen or oxygen atoms . Thus, Ag(I) is employed to react with 4,4′-bpp, and expected to generate some unusual and interesting supramolecular arrays. Two interesting complexes, formulated as [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ-4,4′-bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(1,3-bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Ag(μ-4,4′-bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (1,3-bdc<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) with different types of four-connected square planes and (4,4) topology, have been produced. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the introduction of both 1,3-bdc and flexible 4,4′-bpp with additional conjugated π systems plays an important role in the formation of complex and favors the development of the structure. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, anions <mml:math altimg="si7.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mmultiscripts>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>ClO</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>4</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:none></mml:none>
<mml:none></mml:none>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mmultiscripts>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math> occupy the gap in the squares with metal ions at each corner and 4,4′-bpp ligands at each edge. Herein, the syntheses, crystal structures, the fluorescence properties and the thermal stabilities of two novel complexes of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been described.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: And from a structural point of view, 4,4'-bpp ligand appears to has some advantages: (1) the research on biphenyl bridge containing 4,4'-bpp ligands provides a simple probe for investigation of chiral complexes derived from 1,1-bi-2-naphthol; (2) the flexible nature and the long distance between two pyridyl rings of 4,4'-bpp give rise to the possibility of creating interesting structures with cavities, pores or consequently channels . In addition, Ag(I) ion is a good transition metal precursor for coordination polymers, because it can adopt certain coordination geometries, such as linear, trigonal and tetrahedral coordination modes, and has high affinity for hard donors like nitrogen or oxygen atoms . Thus, Ag(I) is employed to react with 4,4'-bpp, and expected to generate some unusual and interesting supramolecular arrays. Two interesting complexes, formulated as [Ag4(μ-4,4'-bpp)3(1,3-bdc)2] n  ⋅2nH2O (1) and [Ag(μ-4,4'-bpp)2ClO4] n  (2) (1,3-bdc=1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) with different types of four-connected square planes and (4,4) topology, have been produced. In 1, the introduction of both 1,3-bdc and flexible 4,4'-bpp with additional conjugated π systems plays an important role in the formation of complex and favors the development of the structure. In 2, anions     ClO   4     -     occupy the gap in the squares with metal ions at each corner and 4,4'-bpp ligands at each edge. Herein, the syntheses, crystal structures, the fluorescence properties and the thermal stabilities of two novel complexes of 1 and 2 have been described.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">2,2′-Biphenol and 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride were purchased from Acros Ltd. Company and used without further purification, the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. The mass spectra were measured on a Fisons VG platform. The IR spectra as KBr discs were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. C, H, and N analyses were determined on an Elementary Vario ELIII elemental analyzer. Fluorescent spectra were measured on an Edinburgh Instruments analyzer model FL920. Thermal analyses were performed using a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA Instrument and a SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA–DTA Instrument.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General

2,2'-Biphenol and 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride were purchased from Acros Ltd. Company and used without further purification, the other reagents were commercially available and used as purchased. The mass spectra were measured on a Fisons VG platform. The IR spectra as KBr discs were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. C, H, and N analyses were determined on an Elementary Vario ELIII elemental analyzer. Fluorescent spectra were measured on an Edinburgh Instruments analyzer model FL920. Thermal analyses were performed using a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA Instrument and a SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA-DTA Instrument.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complexes

Synthesis of [Ag4(μ-4,4'-bpp)3(1,3-bdc)2] n  ⋅2nH2O (1)

Ligand compound 4,4'-bpp was prepared by 2,2'-biphenol and 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride . The solution of AgNO3 (0.017g, 0.10mmol), NaOH (0.008g, 0.20mmol) and 1,3-H2bdc (0.017g, 0.10mmol) in H2O (5mL) was carefully covered by buffer layer (MeOH:H2O=1:1). Then, the solution of 4,4'-bpp (0.036g, 0.10mmol) in MeOH (5mL) was slowly added above the buffer layer. The light yellow block crystals produced at the buffer layer after a few weeks. Yield: 0.036g (75%). Elementary Anal. Calc. for C44H36Ag2N3O8 (948.48): C, 55.60; H, 3.82; N, 4.42. Found: C, 55.52; H, 3.88; N, 4.36%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3435 (vw), 1602 (s), 1563 (w), 1502 (s), 1461 (s), 1428 (s), 1384 (m), 1351 (m), 1236 (s), 1115 (s), 1053 (m), 1029 (s), 806 (w), 748 (s), 489 (vw).

Synthesis of [Ag(μ-4,4'-bpp)2ClO4] n  (2)

The buffer layer prepared by mixing MeOH and water (the ratio is 1:1) was carefully covered on the solution AgClO4 (0.027g, 0.10mmol) in H2O (5mL). elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals with approximate dimensions 0.48×0.21×0.18mm (1), 0.36×0.15×0.12mm (2) were used for X-ray diffraction analyses. Data were collected at 293(2)K on a Siemens Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Empirical absorption corrections were applied by using the sadabs program for the Siemens area detector. The structures were solved with direct methods and all calculations were performed using the shelxtl package . The structures were refined by full-matrix least squares with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. The positions of H atoms were generated geometrically and treated as riding. Details of the crystal data are listed in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of crystal structures

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that both T-shaped and linear coordination geometries at the Ag(I) centers exist alternately in the crystal structure of 1 with a ratio of 1:1, and 4,4'-bpp ligands, exhibit two crystallographically independent configurations (bpp-A and bpp-B modes) as shown in  .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Ag1 ion displays a <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>-shaped geometry, being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different 4,4′-bpp ligands (bpp-A and bpp-B) and an oxygen atom from the 1,3-bdc. The bond distances of Ag–N, Ag–O [Ag1–N1: 2.187(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Ag1–N3 2.211(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Ag1–O3 2.544(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] and angle of N–Ag–N or N–Ag–O [ranging from 92.88(19)° for N3–Ag1–O3 to 166.90(19)° for N1–Ag1–N3] are comparable to those observed in related structures of silver(I) complexes. The Ag2 center in an almost linear fashion is coordinated by one pyridine nitrogen from 4,4′-bpp ligand and one oxygen atom from the 1,3-bdc ligand. The Ag–N distance and Ag–O distance are 2.117(6) and 2.114(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, and N–Ag–O angel bent to 168° falls in the expected values.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Ligands 4,4′-bpp (bpp-A) coordinate to the Ag1 centers in a <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-bidentate bridging mode, where the dihedral angles between pyridyl rings and the correspondingly linking phenyl rings are 47.3° and 15.1°, respectively, and their two phenyl rings have a drastic twisting with dihedral angle between them being 75.9°. Ligands 1,3-bdc are nearly co-planar and form a dihedral angle of 11.5° between them and 15.4° with the corresponding carboxylate group. And 1,3-bdc ligands where each of the carboxyl groups in monodentate coordination bridges two Ag(I) atoms with the separation of 8.637<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Thus, a highly twisted 50-membered ring with (4,4) topology was formed by four Ag atoms, two 1,3-bdc ligands and two twining 4,4′-bpp ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Interestingly, the <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>-shaped Ag1 coordination leaves an open coordination site pointing towards the adjacent co-ordination polymer chains. Thus, weak ligand-unsupported Ag⋯Ag interactions with 3.008<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å distance between them can be observed, and the pyridyl rings connected by a pair of ligand-unsupported Ag⋯Ag are approximately parallel with a separation between their centroids of 3.348<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, indicating the significant π–π interactions. Thus, the adjacent co-ordination polymer chains are connected by ligand-unsupported Ag⋯Ag reactions and π–π interactions one another to form the 2D sheets (

elements.clean_text: An important feature for structures of 1 and 2 is that they both have the 2D condensed polymeric frameworks, but their 4,4'-bpp ligands exhibit different crystallographically independent configurations and the Ag(I) centers present different coordination modes. Interestingly, T-shaped Ag(I) and linear Ag(I) chains with a ratio of 1:1 exist alternately in the framework of 1, and the weak ligand-unsupported Ag⋯Ag interactions as well as conjugated π systems with additional aromatic rings all favor the development of the structure 1. In 2, the corrugated (4,4) sheets are packed in the ab planes and stacked along the c direction with the anions     ClO   4     -     occupying the gaps in the squares, which supports the compact framework without the presence of interpenetration between adjacent layers.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Fluorescence properties and TGA results</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">As well known, metal-organic polymeric compounds with d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration have been found to exhibit photoluminescence properties and have potential applications in optoelectronic devices and as fluorescent sensors and probes . Here, the photoluminescences of these two complexes were examined (). Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits an intense broad emission band with the maximum intensity at 501<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and a shoulder at ca. 430<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, while complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> produces an intense sharp emission at the maximum ca. 537<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and a shoulder at ca. 430<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with excitation at 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. To ascertain the adsorption of the emission bands, the photoluminescences for free ligands have been measured, in which 4,4′-bpp displays a luminescence at 484<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 1,3-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc at 379<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in the solid state. Generally, the intra-ligand fluorescence emission wavelength is determined by the energy gap between the π and π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> molecular orbitals of the free ligand, which is simply related to the extent of π conjugation in the system. As for the metal complexes, the slightly red-shifted emissions by a factor of ca. 17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> compared to the free ligand 4,4′-bpp, might be attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). And we tentatively assign the shoulder of the emission spectrum at ca. 430<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm to the intraligand emission state from 4,4′-bpp ligand. The different emissions for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> maybe result from their different structures with various coordination geometries of Ag(I) centers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence properties and TGA results

As well known, metal-organic polymeric compounds with d10 configuration have been found to exhibit photoluminescence properties and have potential applications in optoelectronic devices and as fluorescent sensors and probes . Here, the photoluminescences of these two complexes were examined (). Complex 1 exhibits an intense broad emission band with the maximum intensity at 501nm and a shoulder at ca. 430nm upon excitation at 370nm, while complex 2 produces an intense sharp emission at the maximum ca. 537nm and a shoulder at ca. 430nm with excitation at 370nm. To ascertain the adsorption of the emission bands, the photoluminescences for free ligands have been measured, in which 4,4'-bpp displays a luminescence at 484nm and 1,3-H2bdc at 379nm in the solid state. Generally, the intra-ligand fluorescence emission wavelength is determined by the energy gap between the π and π∗ molecular orbitals of the free ligand, which is simply related to the extent of π conjugation in the system. As for the metal complexes, the slightly red-shifted emissions by a factor of ca. 17nm for 1 and 53nm for 2 compared to the free ligand 4,4'-bpp, might be attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). And we tentatively assign the shoulder of the emission spectrum at ca. 430nm to the intraligand emission state from 4,4'-bpp ligand. The different emissions for 1 and 2 maybe result from their different structures with various coordination geometries of Ag(I) centers.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">On the other hand, high thermal stability is an important precondition in the conversion of porous coordination frameworks from laboratory curiosities to practical materials. Thus, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were performed in the temperature range 30–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere. The TGA curves () show that the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit remarkable thermal stability and have an onset temperature for decomposition at about 260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. These results indicate that the complexes are very stable because of their 2D compact frameworks full supported by different kinds of stacking interactions.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

By introducing flexible bipyridyl ligands and using three-layer diffusion methods, we have successfully synthesized two new 2D coordination polymers, [Ag4(μ-4,4'-bpp)3(1,3-bdc)2] n  ⋅2nH2O (1) and [Ag(μ-4,4'-bpp)2ClO4] n  (2). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complexes 1 and 2 exhibit different types of four-connected square planes with (4,4) topology. In 1, weak ligand-unsupported Ag⋯Ag interactions and conjugated π systems with additional aromatic rings favor the development of the structure. In 2, the corrugated (4,4) sheets are packed in the ab planes and stacked along the c direction with the anions     ClO   4     -     occupying the gaps in the squares. The solid-state fluorescent analyses show that 1 and 2 exhibit the intense broad emission bands at 501nm and 537nm, respectively. Complexes 1 and 2 have different (4,4) topological networks, which are different from the helical structures obtained from other synthetic methods in our previous studies . Thus, rational design of coordination polymers from such ligands is still a formidable challenge.

Synthesis of complexes

Synthesis of [Ag4(μ-4,4'-bpp)3(1,3-bdc)2] n  ⋅2nH2O (1)

Ligand compound 4,4'-bpp was prepared by 2,2'-biphenol and 4-picolyl chloride hydrochloride . The solution of AgNO3 (0.017g, 0.10mmol), NaOH (0.008g, 0.20mmol) and 1,3-H2bdc (0.017g, 0.10mmol) in H2O (5mL) was carefully covered by buffer layer (MeOH:H2O=1:1). Then, the solution of 4,4'-bpp (0.036g, 0.10mmol) in MeOH (5mL) was slowly added above the buffer layer. The light yellow block crystals produced at the buffer layer after a few weeks. Yield: 0.036g (75%). Elementary Anal. Calc. for C44H36Ag2N3O8 (948.48): C, 55.60; H, 3.82; N, 4.42. Found: C, 55.52; H, 3.88; N, 4.36%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3435 (vw), 1602 (s), 1563 (w), 1502 (s), 1461 (s), 1428 (s), 1384 (m), 1351 (m), 1236 (s), 1115 (s), 1053 (m), 1029 (s), 806 (w), 748 (s), 489 (vw).

Synthesis of [Ag(μ-4,4'-bpp)2ClO4] n  (2)

The buffer layer prepared by mixing MeOH and water (the ratio is 1:1) was carefully covered on the solution AgClO4 (0.027g, 0.10mmol) in H2O (5mL). Then, the solution of 4,4'-bpp (0.036g, 0.10mmol) in MeOH (5mL) was slowly added above the buffer layer. Over a period of four weeks, the light yellow block crystals formed at the buffer layer. Yield: 0.039g (83%). Elementary Anal. Calc. for C48H40AgClN4O8 (944.19): C, 61.06; H, 4.27; N, 5.93. Found: C, 61.15; H, 4.31; N, 5.91%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3066 (w), 2918 (w), 1596 (m), 1508 (m), 1481 (s), 1455 (m), 1287 (w), 1249 (s), 1234 (m), 1161 (m), 1108 (w), 1059 (m), 1032 (s), 928 (w), 752 (s), 636 (w), 622 (w).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Ag1 ion displays a T-shaped geometry, being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different 4,4'-bpp ligands (bpp-A and bpp-B) and an oxygen atom from the 1,3-bdc. The bond distances of Ag-N, Ag-O [Ag1-N1: 2.187(5)Å; Ag1-N3 2.211(5)Å; Ag1-O3 2.544(5)Å] and angle of N-Ag-N or N-Ag-O [ranging from 92.88(19)° for N3-Ag1-O3 to 166.90(19)° for N1-Ag1-N3] are comparable to those observed in related structures of silver(I) complexes. The Ag2 center in an almost linear fashion is coordinated by one pyridine nitrogen from 4,4'-bpp ligand and one oxygen atom from the 1,3-bdc ligand. The Ag-N distance and Ag-O distance are 2.117(6) and 2.114(5)Å, respectively, and N-Ag-O angel bent to 168° falls in the expected values.

Fluorescence properties and TGA results

As well known, metal-organic polymeric compounds with d10 configuration have been found to exhibit photoluminescence properties and have potential applications in optoelectronic devices and as fluorescent sensors and probes . Here, the photoluminescences of these two complexes were examined (). Complex 1 exhibits an intense broad emission band with the maximum intensity at 501nm and a shoulder at ca. 430nm upon excitation at 370nm, while complex 2 produces an intense sharp emission at the maximum ca. 537nm and a shoulder at ca. 430nm with excitation at 370nm. To ascertain the adsorption of the emission bands, the photoluminescences for free ligands have been measured, in which 4,4'-bpp displays a luminescence at 484nm and 1,3-H2bdc at 379nm in the solid state. Generally, the intra-ligand fluorescence emission wavelength is determined by the energy gap between the π and π∗ molecular orbitals of the free ligand, which is simply related to the extent of π conjugation in the system. As for the metal complexes, the slightly red-shifted emissions by a factor of ca. 17nm for 1 and 53nm for 2 compared to the free ligand 4,4'-bpp, might be attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). And we tentatively assign the shoulder of the emission spectrum at ca. 430nm to the intraligand emission state from 4,4'-bpp ligand. The different emissions for 1 and 2 maybe result from their different structures with various coordination geometries of Ag(I) centers.

On the other hand, high thermal stability is an important precondition in the conversion of porous coordination frameworks from laboratory curiosities to practical materials. Thus, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1 and 2 were performed in the temperature range 30-800°C under N2 atmosphere. The TGA curves () show that the complexes 1 and 2 exhibit remarkable thermal stability and have an onset temperature for decomposition at about 260°C. These results indicate that the complexes are very stable because of their 2D compact frameworks full supported by different kinds of stacking interactions.
